facts.text: Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1944 (Act VI of 1944) was passed in 1944.

Section 4 provides that every dealer whose gross turnover during the year immediately preceding the commencement of the Act exceeded Rs. 5,000 shall be liable to pay tax on sales effected after the notified date.
Appellant, doing contract work on extensive scale for Central Public Works Department and East Indian Railway, comes within definition of dealer under the Act.
Section 7 requires dealer liable under section 4 to register and possess certificate.
Appellant filed application for registration on 19th December, 1944; certificate issued on 21st December, 1944.

On 8th October, 1945, Sales Tax Officer issued notice to appellant to produce accounts on 10th November, 1945, and show cause why penalty not exceeding one and a half times the tax be imposed under section 10(5).
Appellant appeared before Sales Tax Officer, obtained adjournments till 16th March, 1946, and ultimately failed to appear.
Sales Tax Officer assessed tax at Rs. 4,526-13-0 to best of judgment and imposed penalty of one and a half times under section 10(5).
Appellant appealed to Commissioner; appeal dismissed on 6th June, 1946.
Appellant filed revision petition to Board of Revenue against Commissioner's order; dismissed on 28th May, 1947.

Appellant moved Board of Revenue to refer questions of law to High Court; petition rejected by Mr. N. Baksi on 4th December, 1947, with observations: 'No case for review of my predecessors order made out. No reference necessary.'
Appellant applied to Patna High Court under section 21 Bihar Sales Tax Act to require Board to state case.

High Court (Agarwala C.J. and Meredith J.) on 9th September, 1948, declined to call upon Board but remanded: 'The case must go back to the Board of Revenue for a case to be stated or for a proper order rejecting the application to be passed.'
Board reheard, rejected application, refused to state case.
Appellant again applied to High Court to require Board to state case; application summarily rejected.
High Court granted certificate under clause 31 Letters Patent for appeal to Federal Court (originally Federal Court Appeal No. 71 of 1948).

legal_issues.text: Whether the appeal to the Federal Court/Supreme Court is maintainable under clause 31 of the Letters Patent of the Patna High Court from the High Court's order refusing to direct the Board of Revenue to state a case under section 21 of the Bihar Sales Tax Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Resisted preliminary objection relying on Full Bench decision of Lahore High Court in Feroze Shah Kaka Khd v. Income-tax Commissioner.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Clause 31 Letters Patent, Patna High Court; Feroze Shah case

respondent_arguments.text: Preliminary objection that appeal is not competent.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Clause 31 Letters Patent requires final order in original or appellate jurisdiction

court_reasoning.text: High Court order under section 21 is not a final order as it does not of its own force bind or affect rights of parties; it is advisory, with final order by Board of Revenue.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order does not bind or affect rights; merely directs Board to state case if refusal unjustified.

court_reasoning.text: Order not passed in exercise of original or appellate jurisdiction of High Court; no appeal before it.
court_reasoning.key_observation: To attract clause 31, order must be final and in original/appellate jurisdiction.

court_reasoning.text: View in Sri Mahanth Harihar Gir v. CIT (Patna HC) is correct; Lahore Full Bench view not supported by other courts or Privy Council.

holdings.text: Appeal not maintainable under clause 31 Letters Patent as High Court order is neither final nor in exercise of original/appellate jurisdiction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sri Mahanth Harihar Gir v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar and Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Held no appeal under cl.31 Letters Patent from order dismissing application under s.66(3) Income-tax Act (similar to s.21 Bihar Sales Tax Act)

precedents_cited.case_name: Feroze Shah Kaka Khd v. Income-tax Commissioner, Punjab and N.W.F.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Full Bench held appeal maintainable; cited by appellant but not supported by other courts
Privy Council refrained from opinion on competency, dismissed on merits

precedents_cited.case_name: Tata Iron and Steel Company v. Chief Revenue Authority, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court order under reference provision is advisory, not final

precedents_cited.case_name: In re Knight and the Tabernacle Permanent Building Society; Ex parte County Council of Kent
precedents_cited.relevance: Jurisdiction consultative, no judgment or order

statutes_cited.name: Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1944
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs liability, registration, penalty for failure, and reference to High Court

statutes_cited.name: Letters Patent of Patna High Court
statutes_cited.relevance: Jurisdiction for appeal to Privy Council/Federal Court from final judgments etc.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Similar provision to s.21 Bihar Sales Tax Act for reference

outcome.summary: Preliminary objection upheld; appeal held not competent as High Court order under s.21 Bihar Sales Tax Act is neither final nor in original/appellate jurisdiction.

key_quotes.text: "No case for review of my predecessors order made out. No reference necessary."
key_quotes.speaker: Mr. N. Baksi, Board of Revenue

key_quotes.text: The case must, therefore, go back to the Board of Revenue for a case to be stated or for a proper order rejecting the application to be passed.
key_quotes.speaker: Patna High Court

key_quotes.text: The objection is a serious one. Admittedly such an appeal as the present is not authorized by the Income-tax Act itself... their Lordships accordingly refrain from expressing any opinion whatever upon it.
key_quotes.speaker: Privy Council
key_quotes.significance: On competency in Feroze Shah case

key_quotes.text: All that the High Court is required to do under section 21... is to decide the question of law raised and send a copy of its judgment to the Board of Revenue. The Board... has to dispose of the case in the light of the judgment of the High Court.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why HC order not final
